Helpfully, they took a very similar image, using the same instrument, in January 2019 and before the dimming began – allowing them to compare the two images, and understand more about the changes that Betelgeuse has undergone.Rock at the edge of solar system changes our understanding of planetsResearchers now speculate that the star is not in fact about to go supernova, but is undergoing some other, similarly dramatic process. The new research helps give insight into red supergiants like Betelgeuse and what could happen to cause such unusual behaviour.The two scenarios we are working on are a cooling of the surface due to exceptional stellar activity or dust ejection towards us, said Miguel Montargès, an astronomer from KU Leuven in Belgium, who led the new study. Of course, our knowledge of red supergiants remains incomplete, and this is still a work in progress, so a surprise can still happen.Other images taken using the same Very Large Telescope show that the dust around Betelgeuse is emitting infrared light. That appears to happen when the material that makes up the star is spewed back into space.The phrase 'we are all made of stardust' is one we hear a lot in popular astronomy, but where exactly does this dust come from? siad Emily Cannon, a&nbspPhD&nbspstudent at KU&nbspLeuven.Over their lifetimes, red supergiants like Betelgeuse create and eject vast amounts of material even before they explode as supernovae. Modern technology has enabled us to study these objects, hundreds of light-years away, in unprecedented detail giving us the opportunity to unravel the mystery of what triggers their mass loss.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Bank seeks to clean up&nbsptoxic image that has built up through its association with the financial crisis, massive losses&nbspand poor&nbsptreatment of customersRoyal Bank of Scotland is to be renamed NatWest Group as the bank attempts to rescue its tarnished image after more than a decade of scandals and a £45bn taxpayer bailout.Howard Davies, the chairman of&nbspRBS, said that&nbspNatWest,&nbspone of its subsidiaries, was a more appropriate moniker for the bank, which has&nbspshed its riskier businesses to focus on the more mundane business of high-street lending.&nbspIt will also go some way to rid RBS of its association with the “too big to fail” excesses that led to the financial crisis and the turmoil of the years that followed. RBS&nbspwas found to have mis-sold complex financial products to small-business customers in a bid to boost its own bottom line, while its infamous Global Restructuring&nbspGroup destroyed firms to sell off their assets for a profit.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Davies&nbspsaid: “The essential reason for this is, as the bank has evolved from the financial crisis and the bailout, we have focused on the NatWest brand.“We have exited a lot of the international businesses which were not profitable. That was branded RBS and that’s gone.“It really makes no sense for us to continue to be called&nbspRBS. title: elton john leaves stage tears crying walking pneumonia auckland new zealand
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Singer told the crowd he was ‘so very sorry’ after he lost the ability to performElton John left the stage in tears on Sunday night (16 February) after he lost the ability to sing.He was forced to stop performing midway through the concert, which took place at the Mount Smart Stadium in Auckland, New Zealand.“I’m sorry, so very sorry,” Sir Elton told the crowd. “My voice is shot.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe superstar, 72, then began to cry as the audience cheered him on, before staff came to help him off stage.&nbspCreated with Sketch.18 of the greatest gigs ever – according to our critics Show all 18Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The long gone Rainbow in London’s Finsbury Park was one of the great rock venues, and though I was young at the time it would be impossible to forget the impact of Bowie in one of his first outings as Ziggy Stardust. “They haven’t even finished building the stage,” I said with breathtaking naievety to the person next to me, on observing the scaffolding and ladder. Of course, it was all part of the Ziggy theatrics, a show that began with DavidZiggy walking out to the drums of “Five Years” and continued with mime, flamboyance and songs that have all become classics. I remember his appearance being heralded by music from Beethoven’s Ninth (also used in A Clockwork Orange, the film being current at the time). In those years Bowie always used it as his theme music. I also remember being blown away by the support act – a fresh, imaginative outfit called Roxy Music. (David Lister)Truly charismatic performers leave an indelible impression and I marvelled at the way Chuck Berry had the crowd in the palm of his hand when I saw him in the 1970s. But few could match Dolly Parton in her prime for her larger-than-life enthusiasm and sheer sense of fun. When the country superstar came to London’s Dominion Theatre in 1983, she played some mean finger-picking banjo, sang beautifully, especially on an a capella version of “Do I Ever Cross Your Mind?” and even did an Elvis impression. Her concert was filmed for a video release and about half an hour after the crowd had left in, they brought in a large group of young punks and Goths (to intercut into crowd shots) and suggest an edgy young following. Happily, I had stayed around and saw her deliver this impromptu extra set, which was full of risqué jokes and blue banter. There’s no one quite like her. (Martin Chilton)You don’t usually realise you’re present at what will become a moment in history. But that sunny July afternoon at Wembley Stadium felt special right from the off, even if the off was Status Quo doing “Rockin’ All Over The World”. There were numerous stand-out moments perhaps on paper the biggest was the return of Paul McCartney, topping the bill after nearly five years self-enforced absence from high-profile performing following the shooting of John Lennon. Somewhat sadly the sound failed for part of “Let It Be”, but we can draw a veil over that. The most stunning set of the day came from Queen: a high energy medley through “Bohemian Rhapsody” and “Radio Ga Ga” to “We Will Rock You” and “We Are The Champions”. No one fired up the crowd quite as much that day. And since the band had not been at their most visible around that time, this proved to be their resurrection. (David Lister)Blues titan BB King released two of the greatest concert albums of the 20th-century in Live at the Regal (1964) and Live in Cook County Jail (1971). Even though he was 60 when I saw him at London’s Hammersmith Odeon in 1985, he was still full of energy. He sang with passion and his guitar work was transcendent, especially on gloriously funky version of “The Thrill is Gone”. I skipped my graduation ceremony for the concert and had the good fortune to bump into an old family friend called Ray Bolden, who had worked at Dobell's Record Shop in Charing Cross Road. King's face lit up to see Ray, who had put him up in his London flat in the 1950s. The blues superstar could not have been friendlier, despite his tiredness after a long gig. Seeing Muddy Waters live in 1979 was special but BB King at full power, bending guitar notes like no one else, topped even that. (Martin Chilton)When The Jesus &amp Mary Chain reached the status of noisenik godheads with their fourth album Honey’s Dead in 1992, they decided to put together a visceral modern rock revue tour called Rollercoaster that’s still ringing in my ears almost 30 years on. Of the three revolving support acts, Blur opened the night, mid-transformation from baggy latecomers to art-pop pioneers. With Damon Albarn flinging himself wildly around the stage and clambering up amp stacks, they premiered ferocious second-album character studies like “Colin Zeal” while screening films of the journey of meat from slaughterhouse to defecation, in reverse. Most crucially, with their all-horns-blazing new single “Popscene”, they kick-started Britpop right before our eyes. The Mary Chain, meanwhile, were at peak malicious, I left with my skull buzzing, my eyes opened and my tastes re-arranged, convinced I'd seen the new music, and I had. A gig that didn’t just make my night, it made me. (Mark Beaumont)When Pixies came onto a London stage on my birthday in 2004 and played Pixies songs – and music just doesn’t get better than that – it was pure relief, euphoria and dark-hearted epiphany. “Tame” sent me feral, “Gigantic” was titanic, “Bone Machine” crushed out my marrow. Black Francis snarled, barked and ranted through “Gouge Away”, “Monkey Gone To Heaven” and “Debaser”, every bit the demented pervert preacher he ever was Kim Deal’s angelic coos and bass melodies made an unholy pact with Joey Santiago’s werewolf guitar riffs, seemingly played with a plectrum made of Satan’s fingernail. Of their four Brixton dates that week, I lost every ounce of my s*** at three. Best gigs ever, no particular order.North London’s tiny and now-defunct, Buffalo Bar in the 2000s, hosted early gigs from the likes of Bloc Party, The Libertines, The Maccabees – or Foals. Their show took place 14 months before the release of their debut album Antidotes, and it justified their precocious reputation as a live act. That night, the energy of their high-octane math-rock was infectious it’s not often that you see a band in their earliest days and know that this is probably the last time you’ll be able to reach out and touch them. The songs followed: The French Open, Balloons, Hummer”, “Mathletics”, all fuelled by astoundingly complex polyrhythms, interweaving staccato synths and guitar played high on the fretboard in angular electro harmonies, set to punk-disco techno beats and urgent new wave vocals. I’d never seen a rock gig so precisely engineered (a sticker on the synth read Math is for Everyone), yet so exhilarating. There was a true sense we’d discovered something great. (Elisa Bray)Problematic in every way given singer Alice Glass’s October 2017 statement accusing her former bandmate Ethan Kath of sexual abuse, non-consensual sex and controlling behaviour, but this short set in front of a small crowd in a Camden bar was proof that when a performer truly plugs into the mother lode, the intensity they generate can burn itself into your retinas and shake your soul. Glass was 19 years old, and for most of the set just a blur of spectral movement frozen into violent shapes by an almost incessant strobe singing, shouting and screaming her way through songs such as “Courtship Dating”. The result was a reminder that whenever one of your heroes gets on stage to try to channel that primal essence of “rock ’n’ roll” – or whatever the hell it is – most of the time, they’re just trying to find an echo of something that once flowed through them. That can go on for 50 years or more. There’s sadness now in the memory, but on this day in April 2008, Glass had it. I’ve seen Cave perform scores of times and he has never let me down, but this show, which coincided with the release of the album Dig!!! Lazarus Dig!!!, was a whole new level of spectacular: funny, furious, life-affirming, heavy on the biblical melodrama. And yet Cohen, in his mid Seventies, is barely breaking into a sweat. Much like his attire, the songs - such as Dance Me to the End of Love and So Long, Marianne – are immaculate, his voice no longer a wail but a raw, rumbling baritone. A gig that didn’t just make my night, it made me. Of their four Brixton dates that week, I lost every ounce of my s*** at three. Premium.Tourism industry set to take further hit from coronavirus, adding to impact of higher sales tax and damage from typhoon, experts warnJapan’s economy is on the brink of recession after shrinking dramatically in the final three months of 2019.The world’s third-largest economy contracted 6.3 per cent in the quarter compared with the same period a year earlier, with analysts warning that a further hit is likely to come from&nbspcoronavirus.Tourism has already&nbspbeen negatively impacted, with concern growing that the deadly outbreak may not be contained in time for the Tokyo Olympic Games in July.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAnalysts had been expecting Japan’s growth to slow thanks to a rise in sales tax, the fallout from a powerful typhoon&nbspand the continuing effects of a trade war between America and China.However, the larger-than-expected drop in output was the fastest since 2014, delivering a further concerning sign for the global story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Bank seeks to clean up&nbsptoxic image that has built up through its association with the financial crisis, massive losses&nbspand poor&nbsptreatment of customersRoyal Bank of Scotland is to be renamed NatWest Group as the bank attempts to rescue its tarnished image after more than a decade of scandals and a £45bn taxpayer bailout.Howard Davies, the chairman of&nbspRBS, said that&nbspNatWest,&nbspone of its subsidiaries, was a more appropriate moniker for the bank, which has&nbspshed its riskier businesses to focus on the more mundane business of high-street lending.&nbspIt will also go some way to rid RBS of its association with the “too big to fail” excesses that led to the financial crisis and the turmoil of the years that followed. RBS&nbspwas found to have mis-sold complex financial products to small-business customers in a bid to boost its own bottom line, while its infamous Global Restructuring&nbspGroup destroyed firms to sell off their assets for a profit.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Davies&nbspsaid: “The essential reason for this is, as the bank has evolved from the financial crisis and the bailout, we have focused on the NatWest brand.“We have exited a lot of the international businesses which were not profitable. That was branded RBS and that’s gone.“It really makes no sense for us to continue to be called&nbspRBS. Starmer plumped for Harold Wilson as the best Labour leader, while Nandy said “I’m hoping we are about to elect her.”Asked in a series of quickfire questions how she would vote in a referendum on keeping&nbspthe monarchy, Ms Nandy replied: “I’m a democrat, so I would vote to scrap it, but actually this is not the priority as a country.”Long-Bailey vows to make it illegal for refuges to exclude trans womenStarmer 'not concerned' with being labelled a Blairite or a Corbynista‘Labour will win again only when it comes to love Tony Blair’Sir Keir said: “I wouldn’t. I think I’d downsize it.” And Long-Bailey said: “I wouldn’t vote to abolish the monarchy.&nbspFollowing the death of Love Island host&nbspFlack, who had been the subject of intense scrutiny online and in the media, Ms Long-Bailey said that ministers should revive the second phase of the Leveson Inquiry into press ethics, which was axed by then culture secretary Matt Hancock in 2018.She said: “There's a huge issue to look at in terms of online bullying and social media companies and the way that the press - certainly the tabloids - respond to that and amplify that.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by email“I think we need to ensure that the government puts pressure on the social media companies to tackle online abuse on their platforms.“But I also think that the government needs to press ahead with the second stage of the Leveson inquiry about examining the role of the media within society - a free press but also upholding ethical and moral principles.”Sir Keir said that Flack’s death “shines a torch into the soul of our nation” and highlights the impact of abuse on social media.He said tech companies need to take more responsibility for material published on their platforms.“There’s yards of abuse on social media and it's&nbspabout time that those providing the platform take responsibility for what is on it,” said Starmer.“This has been going on a long time. There’s abuse and hatred and it’s not just Caroline’s case. There are youngsters taking their lives because of what they see on social media.“When I was director of public prosecutions, I tried to persuade social media to take responsibility and their response was, 'If it isn’t terrorism, we are not going to'. That’s got to change now.”Ms Nandy said it had become “difficult to be in public life at the moment, because there is an unkindness that's crept into our public debate that I think is detrimental to all of us”.She said there should be “much greater support” made available to people suffering online abuse.And she added: “I think we need to start challenging the public discourse in this country.“It's not just that it is abusive and unkind, it is also that we have found multiple ways in the last decade to ide ourselves from each other. We're a better country than that. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Labour MP Dawn Butler says she was once escorted out of the members' tea room by securityA majority of black, asian and minority ethnic MPs have said they have experienced racism or racial profiling on the parliamentary estate, a new survey suggests.&nbspOf the 65 MPs from minority ethnic backgrounds in the House of Commons, 37 responded to an anonymous investigation from ITV News across all political parties at Westminster.Of these iniduals, 62 per cent said they had experienced racism on the estate of the House of Commons while 51 per cent said they had experienced racism or racial profiling from fellow MPs.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOver 90 per cent said it was more difficult for them to become MPs due to their ethnicity while 81 per cent added they had experienced racism from members of the public.&nbspShadow women and equalities minister Dawn Butler told ITV News she was once escorted out of a room on the parliamentary estate by security.&nbspCreated with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Teme Street in Tenbury Wells is seen under floodwater from the overflowing River Teme in western England, after Storm Dennis caused flooding across large swathes of Britain. - As Storm Dennis sweeps in, the country is bracing itself for widespread weather disruption for the second weekend in a row. title: coronavirus iphone shortage apple q2 china wuhan latest
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Company says earnings will also be affected by drop in demand in ChinaApple says it will not hit its quarterly earnings target after the coronavirus outbreak led to a cut in production of iPhones&nbspand a fall in demand in China.The company, based in California, said all of its production plants in China had reopened but were only gradually returning to full production. None of its iPhone plants are in Hubei province, the centre of the deadly virus outbreak.Apple had said in late January that it expected its second-quarter earning to be between $63bn and $67bn.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIn a statement the company said: Our quarterly guidance issued on January 28, 2020 reflected the best information available at the time as well as our best estimates about the pace of return to work following the end of the extended Chinese New Year holiday on February 10.Work is starting to resume around the country, but we are experiencing a slower return to normal conditions than we had anticipated. Apple's second quarter ends on 30 March.Senator keeps repeating debunked conspiracy theory about coronavirusWoman sent back to coronavirus quarantine after escaping from hospital'I went through my child's search history and there was coronavirus'US passengers evacuated from cruise ship test positive for coronavirusTrump defends China's alleged cover-up of coronavirus victimsMeanwhile, more than&nbsp300 Americans who were&nbspstuck on a cruise ship affected by the coronavirus were back in the United States after being flown to US&nbspmilitary bases for two weeks of quarantine after spending the previous 14 days docked in Japan.Among those repatriated on two chartered jets were 14 people who tested positive for the virus, seven on each plane. The Diamond Princess cruise ship held the largest cluster of cases outside China, with more than 400 people infected out of some 3,700 on board.The coronavirus outbreak has killed 1,770 people in China and five elsewhere, with Chinese officials reporting another 2,048 cases on Monday, raising the total to 70,548.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Arrangements were made to bring back the 338 cruise ship passengers once their 14-day quarantines on board had expired.Another 60 Americans remained in Japan for monitoring, State Department officials said.A further 200 US&nbspcitizens are stuck in Cambodia, among them 92 still on board another cruise ship, the Westerdam, that was also affected by the virus.The Diamond Princess was ordered to stay under quarantine at Yokohama port on 3 February&nbspafter an 80-year-old Hong Kong man who had been on board&nbspdeveloped the virus.US&nbspofficials previously pledged to keep infected Americans in Japan for treatment. With just a few short months until the first voters flock to the polls, the former governor is running as a centrist and believes he can unite the party's various voting blocsDemocratic presidential hopeful billionaire and philanthropist Tom Steyer is a longtime Democratic donorwebsite lists a host of objectives such as free-at-the-point-of-use healthcare for all, a jobs guarantee, a cancellation of student debts, a wealth tax on the richest 0.1 per cent and a major investment in public housing and green energy.Wealth taxes? Free health care? A jobs guarantee? Isn’t that socialism?Cardi B and Mark Ruffalo among celebrities backing Bernie SandersWhy the rise of Bernie Sanders is making some Democrats nervousWill bitter moderates vote for Bernie Sanders?But while policies such as free universal healthcare are seen as extreme in the US they are perfectly ordinary in Europe.The higher tax and spending proposed by Sanders would also not be out of place on the other side of the Atlantic.The economist Paul Krugman says Sanders is better described as a European-style social democrat rather than a socialist, not least because Sanders isn’t proposing to nationalise private industries.OK, but would this ruin the American economy?The French economist Thomas Piketty even argues Sanders’&nbsppolicies could be beneficial to the US economy&nbspby raising the country’s growth rate, and says that his wealth distribution policies tap into an older tradition of American policymaking.“Remember that the US is actually the country that invented progressive taxation of income and wealth in the 20th century,” Piketty points out.Others have described Sanders as a “New Dealer”, referring to the progressive economic policies put in place by former&nbspDemocratic President Franklin Roosevelt in the wake of the Great Depression of the 1930s.So why are people describing Sanders as dangerous?But it may also be that the genuinely fear Sanders’ policies, even if they are in the mainstream of the European tradition, will do damage in the US context.Or they may be assuming that Sanders, if he won power, would pursue policies that go much further than those he has proposed, with the 78-year-old proving more radical in office, perhaps like Hugo Chavez in Venezuela.Against this, though, is the institutional fact that US presidents are constrained by Congress in what policies they can enact. Sanders might be in favour of relatively radical redistribution, but that’s not true of the wider Democratic party.Even some of Sanders’ rivals for the Democratic nomination, such as Pete Buttigieg, are critical of his policies such as the $15 federal minimum wage.That’s why many analysts – even those who support the principle of “medicare-for-all” – think there is little chance he could actually deliver it, even if he won power.And while some financiers are sounding the alarm, others are more sanguine.Another Wall Street Bank, JPMorgan, recently told its clients that, even if Sanders were elected, “we put the probability of major changes like medicare-for-all or a wealth tax at less than 5 percent.”All of which raises a question: is the risk less that Sanders ruins the US economy than that he disappoints his supporters?Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: labour leadership odds next leader
story: Heres who is most likely to replace him as the next party leader.Nominations from MPs, party members and affiliates have now closed.On February , ballots open for Labour Party members to case their vote.Voting will close on Thursday, April , and the new Labour Party leader will be announced on Saturday, April .Prospective Labour leaders vying to replace Jeremy Corbyn are Sir Kier Starmer, Lisa Nancy,  and Rebecca Long-Bailey.While Labour’s Jeremy Corbyn is yet to stand down as party leader, he has confirmed that he will not run in the next General Election – set to be in May .Here are the odds according to Bet on February :Keir Starmer is the current favourite to take over from Jeremy Corbyn.A YouGov poll revealed a third of the party favour more moderate Keir over other wannabe leaders.Sir Keir Starmer is a clear favourite to take the Labour party over from Jeremy Corbyn.The shadow Brexit secretary is a barrister and politician from London.Starmer worked as a human rights lawyer before becoming an MP, and co-founded Doughty Street Chambers in .The barrister has worked to eradicate the death penalty in the Carribbean, and Africa, and most recently in Taiwan.He worked as human rights adviser to the Policing Board in Northern Ireland, monitoring compliance of the Police Service of Northern Irelandwith the Human Rights Act.In  he was appointed Director of Public Prosecutionsand Head of the Crown Prosecution Service for England and Wales.In  he was awarded a knighthood for services to law and criminal justice, although he prefers not to be referred to as sir.Mr. Starmer was elected as Labour MP for Holborn and St Pancras in May .He was made the Shadow Secretary of State for Exiting the EU in October .The bookies’ second favourite to take out the leadership role, Shadow Business secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey is a fierce Jeremy Corbyn supporter - and could now replace him as Labour leader.Long-Bailey grew up in Old Trafford, Manchester, and worked as a customer service assistant in a pawn shop - something she says taught me more about the struggles of le than any degree or qualication could.She says she became interested in politics at an early age after noticing the struggles my parents and other local families faced.Long-Bailey was elected as MP for Salford and Eccels at the  general election.The constituency consists of a working population whose income is below the national average and higher than average reliance upon social housing.At the end of  the unemployment rate in the constituency stood as five per cent of the population claiming jobseekers allowance, compared to the regional average of . per cent.The constituency voted to leave the EU.Placing third in the bookies’ odds is Lisa Nandy, who has long been touted as a potential Labour leader.The Wigan MP is pitching herself as the candidate who can win back the trust of traditional northern Labour voters who turned to the Conservatives in the  election.In , Ms Nandy was selected as Labours candidate for the Wigan constituency - a seat the party has held for more than  years.She won the seat with a majority of , becoming the areas first female, and first Asian MP.Under Ed Milibands leadership she sat on the opposition front bench as a shadow education minister. She later supported fellow Manchester MP Andy Burnham in the  Labour leadership race - a contest eventually won by Jeremy Corbyn.Under Mr Corbyn, Ms Nandy initially stayed in the shadow cabinet as an energy spokeswoman, but in the wake of the EU referendum she became one of a large group of shadow cabinet ministers to resign in protest at his leadership.Explaining her decision she said Mr Corbyn was unable to form a broad, inclusive shadow cabinet that draws on the best of our movements left and right traditions.The ballot for Labour Party members to vote opens on February  and closes on April .The next Labour leader is expected to be announced on April .Jeremy Corbyn said he would stay in place while the party decides who will take the crown.There is no deputy leader to fill the position after Tom Watson stood down as MP earlier this year.The stakes are high for the party after Corbyns failure to secure dozens of safe seats across the country and the alienation and disillusionment of many voters.A new leader will aim to claw back Labours losses following the  December election.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus uk live updates
story: And now a British couple have tested positive for the deadly virus.Follow our coronavirus live blog to keep up to date with the latest news and updates.Two Brits trapped on the coronavirus-ravaged cruise have tested positive for the virus.David and Sally Abel now have the deadly bug, GMB reported this morning.They are among the  Brits on the Diamond Princess cruise which has been quarantined off the coast of Japan due to coronavirus fears. Around  people have tested positive on the Diamond Princess cruise.It has been in isolation since February . A Chinese city in the Shanxi Province has deployed a fleet of remote-controlled mini-tanks to spray disinfectant in coronavirus-hit communities.It can carry  pounds of spray and have a range of up to  feet,according to Hou Yongfei, deputy director of Shanxi Provincial Drone Association. Mr Hou told Chinese news outlet The Paper: # Now any residential complex with confirmed cases will be disinfected [by them] twice a day.#Concerns over the practice self-isolating are being called into question in China after four members of the same family in Wuhan died.Chang Kai, a director at Hubei Film Studios, died on Friday aged  from pneumonia caused by coronavirus, according to an obituary published by his employer.His father, mother and older sister also died from the disease, according to media group Caixin.Health experts have rasied concerns that home quarantine can lead to more infections.Bizarre face masks that allow wearers to unlock their mobile phones while shielding their mouth and nose have appeared online.The mask can be strapped over the nose and mouth and has an image of the lower half of your face so it can #work with facial recognition software#.Sales of medical masks have gone through the roof in recent weeks is response to the coronavirus outbreak.One issue facing mask wearers is that they render facial recognition software on smartphones – such as Apples Face ID – useless.A San Francisco-based designer claims to have found a way around the issue with a new mask that #looks just like you#. title: lets give the spanish a jolly rogering and nick all that sunken treasure
story: This all sounds very noble until you hear that, actually, what they’re doing is looking for a ship that sank in .Called the Nuestra Senora del Juncal, it was loaded with spices, cocoa, leather and . . .  tons of gold, silver and precious stones.The most recent Spanish treasure galleon to be located, in , was carrying just  tons.And that haul was valued at £million.So God alone knows what  tons would fetch. Billions, for sure.What’s interesting is that the ship did not go down with all hands lost.There were  survivors — and they were able to tell rescuers where the Nuestra Senora had sunk. That information has not been lost.So why are we just sitting back letting Spain and Mexico get on with it Britain needs money for its exciting new railway line and all the hospitals Boris Johnson has promised.Andthere’s a small mountain of it sitting at the bottom of the sea off Mexico’s east coast, why don’t we just sneak over there and help ourselves Certainly, our new six-year-old Chancellor should be considering this . . .  once he’s finished his morning bowl of Frosties and tidied his room.Think about it. We have naval ships in the region waging a hopeless war against South American drug cartels. So why not simply ask them to drive around with their sonar on I feel sure thatthis equipment can find a near-silent Russian submarine gently humming its way through the depths, it would have no trouble at all spotting  tons of gold and silver.Or we could draft in RRS Boaty McBoatface . That’s designed to map the seabed and would be a very useful tool.Frankly, having it in the Caribbean looking for treasure is a much better use of it than having it wandering around Antarctica studying penguins and looking for more dreary evidence of climate change. We know already.I bet the crew would be happier too.Of course, when we do find the loot, Spain will claim it’s theirs, in the same way they say they own Gibraltar.No worries. We’ll just behave like we do when the Greeks say they want the Elgin Marbles back.And Mexico  It’s true the jewels and the gold were sourced from their neck of the woods.But as every schoolboy knows, it’s “finders, keepers”.Britain has a reputation for fair play and decency, but in a cut-and-thrust world we need to be a bit more devious.Maybe then we could find the loot and tell the world we hadn’t. “Nope. Nothing there. Sorry.”IF I were to list all the Bond music in order of greatness – and being a man, EVERYTHING has to be listed like this – Octopussy’s All Time High by Rita Coolidge would be the all-time high.I love Rita Coolidge. She sounds like she’s singing while sitting down.At No, from On Her Majesty’s Secret Service, I’d have We Have All The Time In The World, by Louis ­Armstrong, who sounds like he’s lying down in the bath. And at No it’d be the ­incidental music used during the ski chase in the same movie.I’d have to go a long way down the list – past Mr Kiss Kiss Bang Bang from ­Thunderball, past the music used in the cinema adverts before the film started, and down past the Muzak playing when I took my seat – before I got to the dreary song chosen for the ­latest  outing.Performed by Billie Eilish, it is about as memorable as the middle of a Tuesday night.LIKE lots of box-set enthusiasts, I was captivated by Netflix’s drama The Stranger.“Let’s do one more”, I’d say every night. “Come on. It’s only am.”Set in northern England and starring Richard Armitage, the plot twisted and turned, building to the point that in the final episode I started to wonder how all the endless storylines could all be brought together and tied off.I was intrigued. Fascinated. On the edge of my seat.And then – with a load of stuff still up in the air – it just ended.What I had sat through, then, was a beautully told eight-hour joke. With no punchline.THE BBC has signed up Greta Thunberg to present a new series about monster truck racing in Texas.Only kidding. She’s been signed to present a show on – you’ll never guess – climate change.“I can’t wait. It’ll be so exciting,” said no one.I’VE always said hybrid cars are too heavy, thanks to the fact they have two engines.And now this ­photo of a Toyota Prius proves it.NORMALLY, I’m in full agreement with The Sun’s television critic, Ally Ross.But his review of ­Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Lab show on Netflix was wide of the mark.He described it as “dumb and dangerous”.Wrong, mate. It was way worse than that.At one point, they had two women playing with a vibrator the size of a JCB.And somehow they managed to make the scene even more boring than The One Show.WHENEVER somebody builds a really good bridge, I’ll travel miles out of my way to go and look at it. I realise this is a bit tragic.My favourite bridge in the whole wide world spans the Humber.It’s so graceful and delicate – and when I stand at one end and watch it disappear into the mist on a summer’s morning, I often suffer from a small but embarrassing trouser moment.The only annoying thing about the Humber Bridge is that they went to all the trouble and expense of building it simply to connect the small village of Hessle to the even smaller village of Barton. Two places no one has ever heard of.The fabulous Oresund Bridge was needed because it links Sweden and Denmark.It’s the same story in San Francisco, which has many great bridges that connect the city to the rest of Calornia.That’s the point of a bridge. It links two places that need to be linked.Which brings me on to Boris Johnson’s plan to build a -mile bridge between Northern Ireland and Scotland.Hmmm. I’m aware the Chinese have built a sea bridge this long, but this is a nation that built a whole new coronavirus hospital in SIX DAYS.We are just not that fast. We can’t even build a new railway line without a -year argument.And the fact is that when we finish our new bridge, midway through the rd Century, we will have linked a place called Larne to a place called Portpatrick.Now, I don’t want to have a downer on the plan.Butwe are going to build a -mile bridge over the sea, wouldn’t it be more usefulit went from Dover to Calais Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says control at last
story: A points system will assess each migrant’s talents. If they meet the threshold and have a job offer paying over an estimated £,, they will be let in.Low-skilled immigration will be slashed.Total numbers will fall.This is what Britain voted for.Even the promise of it has calmed anxiety over immigration since the referendum.So it is incredible to see Labour still champion free movement, even outside the EU.Even more so to hear immigration control branded “racist”.It is literally the opposite.We will no longer block skilled staff from India or Africa while admitting anyone from the EU.Boris Johnson now has a Cabinet focused, as one, on forging our new path as an independent nation.Unity of purpose seems to win elections. It’s the best way to get results too.WHEN will Harry and Meghan settle their debt to Britain, give up their handouts and fund their own security They have sacked their UK staff, are closing their office and clearly have no intention of ing. They have potentially already begun adding to their millions by lecturing rich bankers.Fine. But let’s stop paying them through the Duchy of Cornwall too.It morally belongs to the nation.Let’s see our refund for the Frogmore House refit.The Sussexes cut their ties here. We should cut them loose too.TOUCHED as we are by the House of Lords’ concern over journalism’s future, we do wonderthey have ANY self-awareness.“Public trust in journalists has fallen,” says one peer. “The profession is not representative of the population.”Excuse us  A Press read by millions is supposedly out of touch.But not unelected peers who, after failing to thwart a democratic vote, consoled themselves with an inflation-busting pay rise.Is there an institution more reviled or disconnected than the Lords itself MAYBE “Short Man Syndrome” was John ­Bercow’s problem all along.A study shows that smaller footie refs dish out more yellow cards.Bercow’s not a ref. Merely the author of a spiteful book shortly to be found unsold in charity shops.But the portly little Napoleon was forever issuing ­yellow cards from his Speaker’s perch.Now his nemesis Boris is top of the Premier league. And Bercow is relegated to the stands, alone with his grudges.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rose dont be a thorn in natalies side
story: After all, her incredibly brave allegations of rape and sexual assault levelled at the then all-powerful Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein blazed the trail for the #MeToo movement that emerged in .And she has been a fearless activist ever since, pursuing justice and equality.But I’m afraid it was a dud move on her part to criticise actress Natalie Portman for her decision to walk the red carpet at Sunday night’s Oscars wearing a custom Dior gown and cape, which was adorned with the names of some of the female directors who weren’t nominated this year.In her own way, Natalie wanted to shine a lighton the fact that, for the ninth year in the past decade, all five of the best director nominees were male.The female directors highlighted on Natalie’s gown included Lorene Scafaria , Lulu Wang , Greta Gerwig , Marielle Hellerand Melina Matsoukas .Whatever you think about her way of doing it, there’s no doubt she made a point.And the fact that she was standing on the red carpet made it a more powerful point thanshe had, say, boycotted the event or stood outside with a placard.But in a social media post, Rose McGowan referred to ­Portman’s cape as: “The kind of protest that gets rave reviews from the mainstream media for its ­bravery.”“Brave ”, she wrote. “No, not by a long shot. More like an actress acting the part of someone who cares. As so many of them do.“I find Portman’s type of activism deeply offensive to those of us who actually do the work. I’m not writing this out of bitterness, I am writing out of disgust,” she wrote.Unfortunately, coming from someone who has been so integral in the protest movement, this sounds like sour grapes.Natalie’s response to Rose’s criticism was as elegant and as understated as her protest.She said: “I agree with Ms McGowan that it is inaccurate to call me ‘brave’ for wearing a garment with women’s names on it.“Brave is a term I more strongly associate with actions like those of the women who have been testying against Harvey Weinstein the last few weeks.”She also responded to Rose’s accusation that Natalie has only been directed twice by women.But in this criticism, Rose is seriously missing the point. Female directors don’t get as far in Hollywood as male ones, which is precisely what Natalie is pointing out with her cloak protest. Therefore, there are fewer available to work with.As Natalie said: “It is true I’ve only made a few films with women. In my long career, I’ve only gotten the chance to work with female directors a few times . . . Unfortunately, the unmade films I have tried to make are a ghost history.“Female films have been incredibly hard to get made at studios, or to get independently financed. If these films do get made, women face enormous challenges during the making of them.”By the way, this is not the first time Natalie has protested from within the system.While presenting the best director category at the Golden Globes in , she introduced the line-up by saying: “And here are the all-male nominees.”Again, it’s not a shouty, noisy street protest. But it served to make her point. Just that she did it in a dferent way than Rose might. And that’s fine.In fact, some people think that Rose’s in-your-face type of protest risks alienating some people.I think women should support each other when it comes to vying for equality.But also, Rose just sounded spiteful when she said Natalie was “an actress acting like someone who cares”.Rose is a hero to many women. But she needs to understand that whether their contribution is big or small, loud or subtle, anyone’s effort to affect change helps.JANE Fonda, who looked fabulous at the Oscars, has said she is done with plastic surgery.Well, I guess  is as good an age as any to stop nipping and tucking.She must have a great doctor, as whatever the actress has had done has been done very well indeed – because, in my experience, it’s not often you look better after a facelt than you did before.PERHAPS Andrea Leadsom had a premonition that she was going to be axed as Business Secretary in this week’s Cabinet reshuffle.She recently wrote a column obliquely warning Boris Johnson not to cut the number of female ministers in his Cabinet.Addressing the issue of female board members among FTSE  companies, Andrea wrote: “Working in the City in the Nineties, I saw myself how a male-dominated environment can limit a career.”Unfortunately for her, the warning did not save her skin and she has been sacked, along with Theresa Villiers as Environment Secretary and housing minister Esther McVey.By the way, eight of the  members of Mr Johnson’s first Cabinet were female –  per cent.Despite these sackings, that figure has actually risen – slightly – to nearly  per cent.Ideally, the split would be an even -.But the reality is that business and politics can both be brutal.Men and women alike must accept they might one day get the sack.It simply goes with the territory.Being selected on the basis of gender is just as wrong as being sacked on that basis.Right person, right job, regardless of their gender.THAT is what true equality means.SAY what you like about the bonkers lestyle advice dispensed by Gwyneth Paltrow on Goop – and some of it is seriously out there.But whatever she is doing clearly works.She is, at the age of , nothing short of radiant.In fact she looks amazing and also happy.Not only that but she became instantly relatable to parents everywhere with a confession that her -year- old daughter finds her embarrassing.That’s a good reminder there is nothing like a teenager to keep you normal and down to earth for fear that you will embarrass them, no matter what you do.Although, to be fair, perhaps Gwyneth’s daughter has had a predisposition to feel embarrassed by her mother ever since she named her  . . . Apple.What are the ethics of seat-reclining on a long-haul flight An American Airlines passenger raised the question after video-shaming a fellow traveller who punched and pushed her seat when she reclined it.Bearing in mind the recline button moves the seat about in, I suspect this chap has anger issues, as reclining a seat that has a recline button is hardly an act of aggression.I’d disable the recline button and then all you have to fight over is the armrest.DAMIAN Hurleys resemblance to his mother, Liz, is uncanny.More so than ever in the latest shots of the two of them together, which he posted online this week.Some people think it is vaguely unsettling that he looks more like Liz Hurley than Liz Hurley.But as a mum myself, I think it’s heartwarming a teenage boy should be so happy to emulate his mother.OH the utter folly of the face tattoo!The latest to succumb to this trend, which a few years ago would be, frankly, unthinkable, is Amber Rose.She has had the words Bash and Slash tattooed across her forehead in old English manuscript style.It’s a reference, apparently, to the model’s three-month-old son Slash, and six-year-old son Sebastian. And, obviously, it’s lovely that she loves her children so much.But tattooing their names on her forehead where they will remain for all her le  All I can say is: Tattoo in haste . . . repent at leisure.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan and harry by all means demean yourselves but dont demean our queen
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex owe their global superstar status — and their massive earning potential — to their royal connections.That is the wonderful irony about our runaway royals.Harry and Meghan may despise everything about the royal le — the endless scrutiny, the boring engagements, all those fixed smiles for the peasants when they could be hanging out with Oprah and the Obamas and the Clooneys.We get it. We truly do.But do Harry and Meghan understand and ever admit to themselves that they owe EVERYTHING to their royal connections Without the magic dust that royalty bestows, JP Morgan — one of the world’s richest banks — would never have flown them in a private jet to an exclusive company beano. Don’t tell Greta Thunberg!And without his royal blood, Prince Harry would not be in talks with Goldman Sachs about a future relationship.If they were not British royalty, Meghan would be a B-list actress whom few people had ever heard of and Harry an old soldier with two rotten A-levelsfrom Eton — a school where my dog Stan could get four good grades and an offer from Oxbridge.I do not doubt Harry and Meghan’s sincerity when they say they want to be financially independent.But because they are poncing on royal connections, the couple have a duty of care to the Queen and to this country.Please don’t embarrass the Royal Family, or British people who shelled out £million for your wedding.Please do not turn into the preening glove puppets of investment bankers.Oh Harry, please don’t turn into Tony Blair in a tiara.Oh Meghan, don’t become the st-century Fergie.Prince Andrew’s reckless friendship with convicted billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein has humiliated and damaged the Royal Family.Andrew’s total lack of judgment may have done irreparable harm to the monarchy.Many of us wonderthe institution will last after the Queen has gone.So show some dignity, Harry and Meghan. Engage your brains, not your bank balance.Have a little DISCRETION. Please do not pimp your royal connections to any passing dodgy billionaire or investment banker who claims to care deeply about your charity work.Frankly, it doesn’t look good so far.The nation cringed when Prince Harry buttonholed Disney boss Bob Iger at the London premiere of The Lion King, aggressively pitching Meghan’s availability for “voiceover” work.A member of the Royal Family begging a Hollywood big-shot for work was not a pretty sight.When they handed in their letter of resignation, Harry and Meghan made lofty announcements about “collaborating” with the Queen, as though Her Majesty, , is some grime DJ who could be brought in to remix their latest single.The brutal truth is that we will not see much of Harry and Meghan in these parts.This week they sacked  loyal UK staff and shut their Buckingham Palace office.But by turning their backs on the royal le, Harry and Meghan have placed themselves in an almost impossible situation.They claim to want to be financially independent of Prince Charles and the British taxpayer.Then they will have to grab the big pay days where they can.They will have to earn phenomenal sums of money to fund the lavish lestyle to which they are accustomed.But there is absolutely nothing in either of their CVs to suggest they can make that kind of dough without flogging their royal connections to the highest bidder.If Harry and Meghan are going to support themselves, they are going to have to get their hands dirty in the working world.Harry’s discussions with Goldman Sachs may be focused on his charity work right now, but investment bankers are not renowned for their boundless human compassion.Big bankers — and mega-rich companies like Netflix and Apple — will look at Harry and Meghan and wonder what they can get out of them.Harry and Meghan are free to demean themselves, as Harry did so spectacularly when he shook his diamond-encrusted begging bowl at the boss of Disney.But please don’t demean this country.Please don’t debase the Royal Family, as Prince Andrew has done.Please, Harry and Meghan — do not embarrass the Queen.Because let’s face it, chaps — without your royal connections, the pair of you really don’t add up to very much at all.After all those wild decades, Keith – who is said to have smoked an estimated , fags in his time – clearly believes in moderation in all things.Especially moderation in moderation.IN a pithy turn of phrase worthy of Oscar Wilde, one commentator mused that Labour’s dishevelled Tracy Brabin looked like she had been “banged over a wheelie bin” in her off-the-shoulder frock in the House of Commons.Showing Tracy how it is done, Kate Beckinsale looked stunning in a very similar off-the-shoulder number at a pre-Oscars party.Kate also looks as though she has never even seen a wheelie bin.But it’s not true. I recall Debbie Harry was a dazzling double NME winner in  – Pin-Up Of The Year and Best Female Singer.The NME may be  years old. But NME award winners never get any older.THE coronavirus could well be China’s Chernobyl – the national calamity that changes everything.As the global death toll of the virus nears ,, the old men in Beijing who run China have never looked so woefully out of their depth.The greatest hero in China today is Dr Li Wenliang, the -year-old Wuhan doctor who tried to warn the Communist regime of the virus.Dr Li was arrested, bullied, humiliated, accused of scaremongering and later died of the virus.That is what happens in a one-party state that considers all criticism to be treason.China does not look like the next economic superpower today.China looks like an inept one-party state that failed to grasp the seriousness of the virus, then stubbornly refused to heed the warnings that could have contained it, and has now exported it to the rest of the world.The coronavirus came out of the so-called wet markets of China, where every conceivable animal is kept in filthy conditions to cater for the Chinese appetite for “exotic” animals.Wolf pups, koala bears and assorted rats, bats and snakes are all on offer for the discerning wildle gourmet, many under the counter.These markets were the breeding ground for Sars nearly  years ago, and they were the breeding ground for the coronavirus.Exactly how stupid can a regime be that allows the existence of these unregulated markets  The virus that is now polluting the entire planet was totally avoidable.Mikhail Gorbachev was convinced that the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in  caused the collapse of the Soviet Union five years later.The Chernobyl explosion “opened the possibility of much greater freedom of expression”, said Gorbachev. “To the point that the system as we knew it could no longer continue.”If the coronavirus brings down China’s ruling Communist elite, it will be exactly what they deserve.Now Leo has seen his Fine Gael party poll a wretched . per cent of the vote in the Irish general election, going from power to third place overnight.Looks like Leo Varadkar is a teeny-weeny politician now.Now BBC chairman David Clementi squeaks that ending the licence fee will mean scrapping children’s channel CBeebies.Stop our money and you will make all the kiddies cry!But the openly biased BBC stopped being a state broadcaster years ago.It no longer deserves to be funded like one.TANYA McDonnell is a modern success story.Tanya was working in McDonald’s in Washington, Tyne-and-Wear, for £ an hour until a modelling agency spotted her holiday shots on Instagram.“I’d always looked up to people like Kate Moss,” says Tanya. “But I didn’t think I had a chance because I wasn’t pretty enough.”Only in the age of social media could a girl go from having her picture taken on holiday to making a living as a model.And only in the age of social media could someone who looks like Tanya McDonnell fret that she is not pretty enough.I didn’t know he had one.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL title: caroline flack honesty sunshine our life inspired
story: She was also one of the most honest.Unlike so many of our cosseted household names she was approachable, witty and refreshingly open about her own le and struggles.She spoke with candour about her career and her personal le.She was unafraid to open up about her fears and in that way she inspired fans to be open and honest about the problems we all face in le at dferent times.She was a brilliant host of Love Island — funny and insightful without ever being patronising towards the contestants.Her untimely death is a tragedy, the third associated with the show and its future must now be in doubt.The Crown Prosecution Service needs to take a long look in the mirror and ask why it pursued its course of action given what they knew about her vulnerability.We may never know exactly what drove Caroline over the edge.But we will always remember how, like the weather at the TV villa, she brought so much sunshine into our lives.The Duchess of Cambridge’s candour about the joys and pressures of motherhood is to be applauded.Kate’s moving honesty in a new podcast about her feelings of loneliness and “mum guilt” will chime with women across the country.And the fact our future Queen has expressed her feelings so publicly shows how she is subtly modernising the monarchy as well as gaining in self- confidence.The contrast with Meghan and Harry’s complaints about being in the media spotlight will not be lost on the public.While the Sussexes have quit their Royal duties, Kate has kept working hard for her husband and the “firm”.She had to put up with years of jibes about her family and fashion sense, but the nation has now taken her to its heart.We are lucky – and proud – to have this Duchess of Dignity.BRITAIN’S standards in areas like the environment, the minimum wage and workers’ rights are higher than many EU countries.But Brussels is bizarrely demanding that we LOWER our internationally admired regulationswe want to sign up to its tarf-free trade deal.Boris must stick to his mantra of levelling up, not levelling down, and resist the Eurocrats’ race to the bottom.Anything  would betray voters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make title: brexit points based immigration system
story: This Government promised to get Brexit done and we delivered.But that wasn’t our only promise you overwhelmingly backed at the ballot box.We also promised to deliver a points-based immigration system that delivers for the whole of the United Kingdom and this week we will set out plans do just that.On Friday, the new Cabinet backed mine and the Prime Minister’s vision to take back control of who comes to this country.We agreed a radical, new, firm but fair system that rewards the skills people have to offer, not where they come from.Sun on Sunday readers have been with us on this journey.And I can make another promise, that you will finally have an immigration system that works in the interests of our country.For too long firms have relied on cheap, foreign low-skilled labour rather than investing in our workers.They have exploited free movement to undercut you, taking away jobs and driving down wages.For too long we were powerless to help, shackled by Europe and forced to be rule-takers. Ending free movement changes all that.The Government has listened to the clear message from the  referendum and the  General Election that the public wants a reduction in low-skilled immigration.We want to see overall numbers down and this new system will deliver. Our new immigration system will turn off the tap of cheap, foreign low-skilled labour.Workers coming to the UK will have to prove they have something to offer.We are not closing our doors, but we will finally be able to choose who comes through them.We will attract the top talent from anywhere in the world.Allowing us to attract the brightest and the best from around the globe who will help our economy to thrive.From next year, all skilled workers will need to earn enough points to work in the UK.They will need to speak English, have a firm job offer, and meet the salary requirements.Extra points will be awarded to people who have the most to offer, including those working in a profession where there is a real skills shortage.We will continue to monitor – through expert advisers –there are shortages and gaps to be filled.For those coming to work in our NHS and schools, points will be awarded in line with pay scales for their professions.This is only the beginning, and this week we will set out our plans to go even further with a system to deliver the reforms you want.For the first time in decades, the UK will have control over who comes to our great country and how our immigration system works.We’ve got Brexit done, now we’re moving on to focus on the people’s other priorities.We promised to unleash our country’s full potential and we are doing just that. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the mediterranean ghost city varosha summers crumbling ruin
story: The sandy paradise of Varosha in Northern Cyprus was once popular with celebrities such as Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton before the Turkish invasion of  left it completely abandoned.Just fty years ago, Varosha, known as Maras in Turkish, was a thriving tourist hub where the rich and famous could be seen strolling along the sandy beaches.But invasion by Turkish forces on July ,  forced out all of the towns , inhabitants.Since then, it has remained under the control of the Turkish military and fenced off with barbed wire.Signs warn people to keep out and tourists are strictly banned from taking photos across the fence.Beautul homes and apartments have been left in ruins, with overgrown gardens and rotting vegetation.People are now forbidden to enter the fenced-off community, and former residents have been unable toto their homes.A UN resolution of  called for the handover of Varosha to UN control and prohibits any attempt to resettle it by anyone other than those who were forced out.But diplomatic efforts so far have had no success and the town remains in ruins.Cyprus has been ided since  when Turkey invaded the north in response to a military coup on the island backed by the Greek government.The northern part of the island is run by a Turkish Cypriot government and the other two-thirds in the south by the internationally-recognised government led by Greek Cypriots.

title: dad third degree burns vape explodes bomb pocket
story: Richard Bingham, , said the blast from his e-cigarette was so powerful it was like a bomb going off in his pocket.Fortunately for the dad-of-one, he was at Whittington Hospital in Upper Holloway, north London, working when the accident happened and was immediately rushed to AE for treatment.“I could hear a hissing and popping and I was looking around asking what it was, recalled Mr Bingham.Then it stopped and all of a sudden I felt this heat in my pocket and I knew straight away what was happening.“I was trying to get my vape out of my pocket, but it was burning my hand so I couldn’t get it out.Everyone was helping me as I was trying to get my boots undone so I could get my trousers off but it was too late – I was already badly burnt.Now the -year-old has joined London Fire Brigade in supporting an Office for Product and Safety Standards campaign which launches today to highlight the potential dangers of using vapes.He added: “It all happened so quickly, but I have never felt pain like it.I can laugh about it now but I’ve never been so scared – it was like a bomb going off in my pocket.”Mr Bingham added suffered third degree burns on his left leg and also had blistering to his hand where he’d tried to retrieve the vape.The Brigade’s fire investigators believe the keys in Richard’s pocket may have caused the vape’s battery to short-circuit.Ironically, Mr Binghams girlfriend works in a vape shop, but he wasn’t aware that coming into contact with metal items could lead to them exploding.“I’ve been vaping for about four years and have seen videos of them exploding, but you just don’t expect it to go off like that, he concluded.I must have been lucky as I’ve always had change or keys in my pocket — I just don’t think people are aware of the dangers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian spies in ireland undersea cables
story: The move has sparked fears of the possibility the cables could be tampered with, tapped or even cut completely.Irish security services believe they were sent by Russias elite foreign intelligence agency, the GRU, to check out the fiber-optic cables for weak points, The Sunday Times reported.The country has also now ramped up security at landing sites along the Irish coast after the agents were reportedly also seen scouting out Dublin Port.A sprawling network of transatlantic cables run under the worlds oceans to power the internet, texts, calls, and global financial transactions.About % of all intercontinental data is transferred through these cables, according to the Asia-Pacic Economic Cooperation forum.Experts have warned the country could be the new battle space of the future because its a global internet hub and a base for many worldwide tech firms.Ireland is a prime location for these undersea maps because of its proximity to both America and Europe.Irish telecoms company Aqua Comms set up a  million cable in  to connect the US to Dublin then onto London and Europe.Irish police and military insiders now suspect the GRU is using Ireland as an operations base.They fear they have set up on the island to gather intelligence on targets in the EU and the UK, The Sunday Times reported.The revelations come just weeks after a critic of Vladimir Putin was found with his throat slit in what police are calling a politically motivated assassination in a French hotel.Imran Aliev, , was found lying on the ground with multiple wounds to his chest and his throat slit with a bloodied kne next to the body.His is the latest death to spark concerns of a Russian political hit squad running amok in Europe, hunting down any anti-establishment voices in hiding.Dublin is one of Europes largest tech hubs with authorities suspecting the agents could also be spying on large tech firms.Google, Airbnb, Facebook, and Twitter all have bases in the city.Mark Galeotti, an expert on transnational crime and Russian security, said: Ireland doesnt have a counter-intelligence capability.Its a relatively soft target. Ireland is a major node for the global internet.It has a large concentration of tech companies. This is the new battle space of the future.The presence of Russian agents on their shores has also sparked fears of information warfare.John Sipher, a retired CIA officer in Moscow, said there is a high chance the agents are either spying or planning to cut communications.He said: They also may wish to show their capability in order to threaten the West.Our FBI has caught Russians trying to gain access to underwater cables, including the areas where they come into land.They are also seeking to gain physical access to routers and communication nodes.Western countries have long feared that Russia could cut undersea cables, and interfere with the global economy and way of le.Air Chief Marshal Sir Stuart Peach, the UKs most senior military officer, said in December : There is a new risk to our way of le, which is the vulnerability of the cables that criss-cross the seabeds.Can you imagine a scenario where those cables are cut or disrupted, which would immediately and potentially catastrophically affect both our economy and other ways of living Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman pops champagne moves house raffle win
story: Jemma Nicklin bagged her first home for the jaw-dropping bargain price and called the four-bed Shropshire pad her dream house.And she revealed she had spotted the competition advertised on Facebook - sold by Michael Chatha through the draw after it failed to sell on the conventional property market.Ms Nicklin, an admin assistant at community transport company Ring And Ride, found out she had won the house valued at £, on Friday.She said: Im still in shock. Not one single thought has processed in my head since the day I found out.I was looking through the photos and I said to my mum Do you think I should have a go  and she said Why not  Youve got to be in it to win it.I thought it looked so lovely. Ive always loved the countryside, me and my family would go for walks in the countryside quite often. Its got so much character.The farmhouse, which also features three bathrooms and a self-contained annexe, is nearly  miles away from her family home in Bilston, Wolverhampton.Ms Nicklin said she does not know when she will move in to the property, adding that her family and friends have not yet come to terms with her enormous prize either.She added: I think its going to take years to get used to, its just one of those things you never expect to happen.My whole family are still in shock.It has just a crazy, crazy impact, one I could never have imagined. Its le-changing.Ms Nicklin said she was very grateful for Mr Chathas decision to put the house up for the competition.The old property has exposed beams in every room and a farmstyle kitchen with a walk-in pantry.It even has a library in the living room, with French doors leading to the gardens.Jemma, who earns £,-a-year had started saving for a deposit, but feared it would take years.And Jemma said: Theres just never going to be enough words to thank him, he has changed my le. Ill definitely invite him back around, the doors are always open for him.Mr Chatha, who works in marketing, decided to sell the house after his marriage came to an end.As it had been on the market with two dferent estate agents for eight months but attracted no offers, the -year-old decided to start a website and launch the competition.He told PA: The whole competition went absolutely mad. The house had been on the market for £, and we brought in £, in the first seven days.Weve given this house a lot of love over the last  years and its been a superb family home.We hoped the winner would be someone who was going to give it a lot of love and, having met Jemma and her lovely family, they are wonderful people and were so thrilled, really from the heart, that such lovely people have won the property.Mr Chatha added that all legal fees and stamp duty will be paid for Ms Nicklin using the money, some of which will also be used to finish minor repairs and upkeep of the house.Donations will be made to the Hope House childrens hospice, as well as helping to fund substance and gambling addiction services run by Mr Chatha.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: storm dennis ghost ship ireland drifted months
story: The abandoned cargo vessel Alta was found on rocks in County Cork after the deadly storm battered the British Isles this weekend.The ship had been adrt since the US Coast Guard rescued its crew of ten , miles southeast of Bermuda in October .It was last spotted off the coast of West Africa and is thought to have made its way past Spain and near Cornwall.A jogger spotted the ship when it washed up at Ballycotton on Sunday.Ballycotton RNLI Leboat chief John Tattan told The Irish Examiner: This is one in a million.It has come all the way up from the African coast, west of the Spanish coast, west of the English coast and up to the Irish coast.I have never, ever seen anything abandoned like that before.In October , the Alta, which had been without power for  days, was airdropped supplies by the US Coast Guard while drting , miles southeast of Bermuda.According to the coast guard, the ft Tanzanian-flagged cargo ship was en route from Greece to Haiti when it was abandoned.In September last year, the Royal Navys HMS Protector spotted it in the mid-Atlantic.It said on Twitter at the time: We closed the vessel to make contact and offer our assistance, but no one replied!Whilst investigations continue were unable to give you more details on this strange event.A spokesman for the Waterford Coast Guard said the boat was not polluting the environment.However, it is feared the ship could be taken back out to sea by the high tide,it is not well enough secured.Engineers from Cork County Council are due to conduct pollution assessments on the ship.

title: woman who dated 100 men but stayed a virgin until 41 is now married and pregnant
story: After decades of dating, Amanda McCracken, , found a man who connected with her and was worthy of taking her virginity.She met her dream man - Dave, a drummer from Long Island - in the summer of  at a rooftop with friends.Two months into the relationship, Dave told Amanda she was worthy of his love, prompting her to exchange her virginity for a commitment to positive change, she told Huff Post.The pair had sex for the first time,  months after their first date, in French Polynesia - and married two mother later.Amanda - a Colorado resident who refers to herself as a writer, runner, traveler, and book author - posted to Instagram last week on her birthday to share pregnancy news.She wrote: Grandma’s prophecy has come true. We are expecting a baby end of July early August!As of now, we are waiting until the birth to learn the sex, but we are in awe of our little one already.Amanda, now four months pregnant, published an article on Valentines Day, entitled: I Waited Until I Was  To Lose My Virginity. But Was It Worth it Huff Posts guest writer wrote: It was never about the sex.It was never about waiting for the perfect guy to show up. It was about waiting on a healthy me to show up.The one who realized she deserved more than breadcrumbs. The one who finally felt the emptiness in longing.The one who turned toward love rather than chasing rejection. The one who was capable of accepting that love.And that was worth the wait.Amanda opened up about dating more than  men by the time she was -year-old.She wrote: My romances, which lasted from one night to one year, were with men from  years younger to  years older.I dated a physicist, army captain, stripclub bouncer, philosopher, professional country singer, peace-treaty negotiator, yacht captain, waste management baron, professional athlete, farming landscape painter, firefighter, ER doctor, retired CIA spy, minister, a handful of lawyers and enough engineers to start a firm.She revealed that although she was intimate with more than  of the men, she still refrained from having sexual intercourse.I knew in my gut that I wanted to experience sexual intercourse within a mutually loving and committed relationship. That relationship just never came along, she wrote.Amanda first opened up about her decision in , in a New York Times essay she wrote, titled Does my Virginity Have a Shelf Le It led her to speak on the Katie Couric show - which she claims on a commercial break the show host said she was suffering from fairytale princess syndrome.At one point, Amanda questionedher expectations for love and commitment were too high - but ultimately she decided that wasnt true.In a recent interview with BBC World News, she is happy with her decision to wait for sex.She said: I wanted to be in a relationship where there is that mutual love and commitment. And I believed it existed.It was worth the wait but not in the way people would think. The sex was great, but the journey was never about the sex.Im now with in a loving and committed relationship with a man who can offer me love.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
